dataIdInfo.idPurp: This is the theta look vector map for a pair of Sentinel-1 SLC granules, processed using GAMMA software. The pixel values indicate the SAR look vector elevation angle at each map pixel, ranging from -pi/2 (down) to pi/2 (up). It is a 32-bit float GeoTIFF projected to WGS 84 / UTM zone 18N, and has a pixel spacing of 80 m.
dataIdInfo.idAbs:
This is the theta look vector map for a pair of Sentinel-1 SLC granules, processed using GAMMA software. The look vector elevation angle is defined as the angle between the horizontal surface and the look vector (pointing back towards the sensor), with positive angles indicating sensor positions above the surface. The pixel values indicate the SAR look vector elevation angle at each map pixel, ranging from -pi/2 (down) to pi/2 (up), expressed in radians. It is a 32-bit float GeoTIFF projected to WGS 84 / UTM zone 18N, and has a pixel spacing of 80 m.

Reference Scene: S1A_IW_SLC__1SDV_20181008T230617_20181008T230644_024051_02A0D6_DD03

Secondary Scene: S1A_IW_SLC__1SDV_20181125T230617_20181125T230644_024751_02B91E_B663

Processing Date/Time: 2021-11-15T16:40:08+00:00

An important use of look vectors expressed in map geometry is the interpretation of 3D surface deformation. The main application is monitoring landslides and glaciers, where there is the assumption of motion along the gradient of the topographic height. Differential interferometry permits the deformation component in the SAR look direction to be estimated using the displacement component in the look direction and the direction angles (elevation theta and orientation phi) in the map geometry. The GAMMA program dispmap_vec can be used to perform these estimations.

This raster can also be used to calculate an incidence angle that accounts for elevation differences but not slope angle, by subtracting the lv_theta value from pi divided by 2. This calculation is often used when applying an atmospheric correction. It is also used when recalculating vertical displacement values from an unwrapped phase raster adjusted to a new reference point.

Refer to ASF's InSAR Product Guide for more information about On Demand InSAR products.

The Sentinel-1A satellite was launched April 3, 2014, and the Sentinel-1B satellite was launched April 25, 2016. The satellites each have a 12-day repeat cycle. More information about the mission is available at https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/missions/sentinel-1.

Additional information about Sentinel-1 data, imagery, tools and applications is available at https://asf.alaska.edu/data-sets/sar-data-sets/sentinel-1.
dataIdInfo.idCredit:
When using this data as an image in a publication such as journal papers, articles, presentations, posters, and websites, please include the following credit with the image (portions in square brackets are optional):
[InSAR product processed by ]ASF DAAC HyP3 2021[ using GAMMA software]. Contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data 2018, processed by ESA.
When using this data in a manuscript and/or crediting datasets used for analysis, an acknowledgement including the software versions may be appropriate:
ASF DAAC HyP3 2021 using the hyp3_gamma plugin version 5.1.1 running GAMMA release 20210701. Contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data 2018, processed by ESA.
For more information on citing the dataset, please refer to the README file distributed with this product.

Consts.useLimit: There are no restrictions on the use of this data, but it must be acknowledged or cited as listed in the credits.

dataIdInfo.envirDesc: This product was generated by ASF DAAC HyP3 2021 using the hyp3_gamma plugin version 5.1.1 running GAMMA release 20210701.

dataLineage.statement: The theta look vector map is generated from the SLC parameter file using GAMMA's look_vector program. Refer to the product readme file for details on the InSAR processing workflow.
